REY:
What's the matter?
Cross over the street. I want to look at this building. Let me see
where are we?
This is the Bowery.
And this is Bayard Street. Now look at that hotel.
The North American Hotel. One, two, three, four, five floors, and
an Exchange Stable attached....
Never mind that! What I want you to notice is...
But I do mind it. I want to notice everything; and make a note.
Look on the roof, beside where the .American Flag is flying. There is
a wooden statue of a poor boy with ragged knees and elbows. Why
should the management put such a thing on their roof. Surely there
must be some instructive story connected with it.
Yes, sir, there surely is. (HE MAKES THEM JUMP)
I beg your pardon!
That's all right! Now, I guess you two gentlemen are foreigners.
Foreigners? We are Frenchmen.
In America we are foreigners.
And you figured there was a story to that statue on the North American
Hotel. I'll tell you that story; and you'll find it's a tale of American
industry, American opportunity, and American courage.
Are those things abundant here?
Sir: those virtues (and many others besides) are always found in
America, and never found in other countries. Now, sir, thirty eight
